title: On 1 September 2020, how many states will report a COVID-19 fatality rate of 5.0% or higher?
preds: Still 7 states. Unlikelyone of those states dereasing to less than 5%. Update tomorrow but not til late tomorrow.

7 states have no chance. The two closest are Michigan and Pennsylvania.
Both need to have significantly higher caseloads than they currently have to get below a 5.0% fatality rate without having any more deaths. It is highly unlikely their caseloads are going to increase significantly (50+%) enough without a corresponding amount of deaths to go below the 5.0% fatality rate.

Even with very generous margins of safety for new cases (that is, assuming they're substantially higher than their August average so far) and assuming no new deaths, CFRs can't plausibly drop below 5% in 7 of the remaining states. There would need to be a BIG surge in cases in the next 3 weeks, which looks very unlikely for now.
Currently 7 with more expected in August but less than 12.
Very unlikely to double from current 3.1% by 9/1.

Belatedly did some more modelling. In essence: Currently 8 states over 5%.  Of these, 5 seem sure to stay above 5%, given very slow declines over the last month (Con, Mass, NH, NJ, & NY). 3 are more borderline (Mich, RI, Penn). So I fired up the spreadsheet to look at these more closely. Michigan: The track record for Michigan is almost ruler-straight decline over the last month by ~0.05%/day. Extrapolating this forward to resolution date gives 5.6%.  RI: If you stare at the graph you can persuade yourself the rate of decline has accelerated recently. If you crudely model this with a quadratic fit and extrapolate forward you get ~4.3% at question close. (Or being more basic: it was 5.7% at the start of last month, 5.3% at the start of this one, so ~4.9% at the start of the next). Penn: Similar to Mitchigan, very straight declines (~0.05%/day). So extrapolating out gives ~5.2% To drop into the lowest bucket, 2 of these states need to decline faster than these projections. They don't have to go much faster, and there's a fair forecast error (drawing lines on time series is the opposite of robust technique), but still feels fairly unlikely, ergo some fractional tightening. I expect to be looking carefully over the next weeks to see if the expected rates are lining up. (Several states are showing fractional upticks in their CFR over the last couple of weeks. None of these are likely to add any 'new' states into the 5%+ bracket, but if the mechanism is right censoring (i.e. you only find out later how many cases survive) it could somewhat slow the decline in CFR in places which diagnosed more cases ~a month ago then they are doing now.)
And why wasn't Puerto Rico added to this chart? Currently I count 8 meeting the criteria with 4 weeks remaining in the period.

Right now there are 8 states with CFRs above 5. High CFRs seem to be pretty closely related with low testing, and I don't see testing significantly being reduced in the next month.  So we'll start here.

Still sitting at 8, we have 30 days to add or subtract a state. Growth in some states has ebbed. We are likely to wind up with just 7 states meeting the criteria. But stranger things have happened, so I'll also fill the lowest bucket.
Currently only 8 states are showing to be higher than 5%.

Most probable will stay at 8 above 5%. Could feasibly go to 7 or 9. Very unlikely from the current rates and especially the numbers already in place for two more states to go below 5%. Current outbreaks are generally coming under control so a massive shift in 6+ states to get the total up to 13 is near-impossible.

I believe the total number of fatalities nationally is currently under-counted (at appx. 140,000). However, I believe the current number of infections is also under-counted, and at a higher rate. I am not a denier of Covid-19 and I believe it is serious.  In, fact, I do not believe schools should reopen in august for in-person classes.   This question is VERY hard to predict because the concept of the spread of the disease and its prevalence is not directly related to the amount of testing.  Looking at the chart many of the states that have the highest fatality rate were those hardest-hit earliest. We know deaths lag by 3--5 weeks, at least, after a spike in new cases is observed.  However, with the most recent problem areas infections in younger people seem more prevalent, as well as more testing overall, which both lower the measured fatality rate.   I have zero confidence that the overall disease spread will be tempered between now and September 1.  In fact, I expect it to be worse nationally then.  However, if we can sustain the same testing rates we currently have (if not improve them) I believe the measured fatality rate will go down, even though (shamefully) the number of fatalities could easily be at 250,000 by September 1.
I'm trusting the people I admire here, knowing full well C19 has been a weak spot for me.
While positive test rates are increasing, I don't think mortality rates will increase as quickly.

Chances are it will remain around the current level.  Split between increasing and decreasing due to so many unknowns (constantly evolving new therapeutic options could spin numbers down vs random clusters in assisted living facilities/high risk age group locales could swing them up). Possible further sowing of distrust and/or creatively curating data to spin for one political party or the other.  Many extra variables from other realms.
The fatality rate is a function of total confirmed cases and total deaths. As long as universal testing is unavailable the fatality rate will remain artificially high.

Did some more number crunching on rates in the remaining 8 states. Of these, 5 (Con, Mass, NH, NJ, NY, RI) either show fractionally increasing or essentially static CFRs, so little chance of any of these falling below 5% (with some possibility for RI as it is already close to 5%).  Both Penn and MI show mild accelerations in their decline (i.e. the drop from Jul 12-22 was ~10-20% higher than from Jul 2-12. If you increment forward this difference in different linearly until resolution Michigan falls just below 5% (4.9) and Penn lies just above.  Neither method should be trusted (e.g. naive extrapolation gives some states with negative CFRs, tracking forward the increment gives large swings (e.g. Arizona rises above 5% again). Also this makes no attempt to adjust for other factors (e.g. off-trend increases in testing, right censoring for some emerging/rumbling outbreaks). That said, widening slightly given it is looking fairly close for 2 more states to put into the first bin.  I'll reassess in the next 10 days to assess what the acceleration etc. has been doing.

Long term, fatality rate should be sub 1.0%. So the more testing that is done (and more cases discovered), the fatality rate should trend down. And the US should hit 1 Million tests per day soon.  But, I am concerned about states like NY - which still shows a fatality of 6.x%. So as testing follows outbreaks, there is a chance that reported fatality rates in many states will be higher than 5.0%.
No doubt about 8 or fewer. No chance for New York, Michigan, Massachussets, New Jersey and Connecticut. So it´s 6-8.

Dumb linear extrapolation since the start of Jul out ~50 days to resolution gives ~9 states >5% (all bar Indiana). In terms of bins, it is very hard to see ways to cross to 13 or 6.  For the former, nationwide CFR, as well as those for essentially all states below 5% on downward trends (plus the theoretical point that IFR is substantially lower and so even inadequate testing may be enough to 'find enough cases' for the deaths observed). For the latter, the 3 most likely states to drop below 5% are these:  DC: Now 5.26, was ~5.3. Not dropping fast (and not all that many cases), but already close to the cusp.
Penn: Now 7.28, was ~7.6. Some hints of accelerating decline, and some incidence to drive 'case-finding dilution'.
Rhode Island: Now 5.64, was ~5.7. Similar to DC, albeit further away.  The others are remote, either with ~static trends and well north of 5%. The conjunction of DC+Penn+RI holds at least the plurality of scenarios of '6 or fewer', and looks pretty remote.  The US may be beginning to see an uptick in mortality rates. I don't see this as credible to reverse the downward trends, but may mitigate them. I'm slightly wider than the argument above, owed to model uncertainty and it this feels a little hedgehoggy, notwithstanding forward prediction has been good so far.

I had a first principles story as to why we should expect there to be a nationwide trend towards increasing CFRs. Test positivity ratios are generally increasing, which typically means worsening case ascertainment, and so inflating (observed, crude) CFR above the IFR of (typically) 1%. On this story (and if you assume the epidemic will continue to grow over the next couple of months) you would expect more states to cross 5% than the current 12.   Yet, at least according to our world in data[1], crude CFR has been *declining* in the US as a whole since mid May. Moreover, when I check previous captures of the page we are forecasting, CFRs have been incrementing down over most states over the last 8 days or so. When I compare previous captures and do extremely dumb linear extrapolation, 3 of the states >5% now will fall below 5% at resolution (Ind, Ken, OH), the others remain ~stable, and none currently below 5% rise above it.  There are manifold general corrections which are relevant (e.g. right censoring, changes in testing trends, seasonality, reporting protocols, and latencies galore), as well as closer analysis of particular states. In aggregate they point to increasing CFRs. Engaging mechanistically, though, I think there's a stronger consideration pointing in the opposite direction: the 'inflation' you get from undertesting is non-linear, as severe cases are preferentially tested. As a benchmark. Wuhan near the peak of its epidemic (with, to my understanding, testing mostly limited to those presenting with symptoms, ICU/hospital capacity problems, so on) still did not report a CFR >5%. Even fairly indifferent testing regimes may be sufficient to 'dilute' fatalities with cases to reduce CFR < 5%, as *hospital fatality rates* can be lower than this.[2] Thus a Simpson's paradox-esque story: although prevalence outstrips testing, the testing increases are sufficient to reveal proportionately more of the 'sub-clinical' (or just 'sub-lethal') iceberg to drive down crude CFR (as a further paradox, states which are losing control of their epidemics stand a *better* chance of reducing their CFR below 5% than those which are bringing it under control - hence why CFR is a treacherous metric).  [Aside, toy example: Suppose 1000 infections, 10 deaths (IFR 1%), and 1000 tests at test positivity of 1%. Presuming you test all the deaths first, then use the remainder randomly on the population, you get 10 cases from the deaths, and find ~10 non-fatal, so a CFR of ~50%. Suppose the epidemic increases by an order of magnitude in size whilst your testing merely doubles (so test positivity is now 10%, IFR unchanged). So now 100 cases from the deaths, plus ~290 other cases, so the CFR has fallen from 1/2 to 1/3.]   However, bitter experience teaches dumb numerical models often do better than people trying to vaguely weigh up qualitative considerations in their head (especially for COVID, the numbers seem to be often gravity-defying by my intuition). Thus I'll mostly stick with the dumb extrapolation, and add more snapshots over the next few weeks to detect trend reversal (and assess forward prediction for intermediate times). I might also kick the tires more on my 'simpsons paradox' story (i.e. how well do increases in aggregate testing rates explain declines in CFR), and if so refine the forecast looking at the 12 or so states (+ any borderlines). Hopefully I'll quickly correct any overconfidence. [1]: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-states?country=~USA
[2]: https://www.cebm.net/covid-19/declining-death-rate-from-covid-19-in-hospitals-in-england/

The states that have >5 now are not likely to find enough new cases to drop below 5%. Of the major outbreak states (California, Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, Georgia etc) at least 2 will go above 5% once the lag in deaths has passed.
infection rates are climbing in several states - and while death rate national has decreased to about 5%, it will likely climb, especially in states that are experiencing a spike in cases

current nation-wide death rate is trending toward 5% overall - with infection and hospitalization numbers growing in several key state it is likely that at least half of state will report that rate at the start of September

I'm choosing to depart from the crowd here. Of the current 13 over 5%, I only see a realistic possibility of 2-3 of them dropping under 5%. Example: New York would required something like 500k new cases at a low death rate to get there. This is possible but unlikely. Here are some scenarios: 
1) massive new wave starting in August where there are a lot of cases but deaths lag into September
2) far more extensive testing could result in many more asymptomatic cases being detected. However this would require a number like 1M new cases detected to make the numbers work. 
3) Most likely: they redefine the case numbers and could people with positive antibody tests and that suddenly drops everyone including NY below 5%. On the other hand there are a few under 5% with a good chance of going up. Example Arizona: Currently their death rate looks low relative to other states because most of their cases are recent and unfortunately there are deaths yet to come. The numerator hasn't caught up with the denominator. Also if they hit ICU capacity then they will potentially have actual case mortality rates in the 5% range.
Today‘s number is 12. Because an increasing number of tests as well as confirmed test the fatality rate is now decreasing.

True mortality rates in any developed country are little more than 1%. This is backed by antibody tests. UK ONS antibody tests estimates 6.3% (possibly > 8%) of population has been infected (4.2 million) with 45,000 fatalities = 1.07%. This should now reduce significantly with new therapies.
I agree with @Bobbiekar52 the question is really asking how poor each state's testing is.

I wish I hadn’t participated in this one, I almost didn’t.  I am reducing my spread evenly because the data being reported  is inaccurate and incomplete.  From what I can see, the fatality rate is a reflection on the ability and willingness to test.  All states are infected with the same virus. The % of fatalities from the disease should only vary slightly based on age and perhaps outbreaks within nursing homes.  Of course, the more people you have Infected, the harder it is to confirm numbers of infection, meaning the infection fatality case rate will go up. But as test supplies become more limited, this will also impact the number in this set of data.  In other words, we are measuring our ability to evaluate the situation, not the situation itself.

Death rate to that value may be prevented in two ways: 1) stop the spread of the virus, self-evidently, and prevent hospitals from being overwhelmed.
2) Dr Joseph Varon, UMMC Houston, TX, reports about keeping patients from being admitted to ICUs and especially off the need for ventilator by successful individual combinations of treatments.
These treatments include: blood thinner to prevent blood from clotting
Heparine, cortisone and vitamins (antioxidants?) against the damaging effects of systemic inflammation. Once people are so sick they need to be ventilated, survival rate is said to be about 20 per cent only. I wonder how these best practices spread among hospitals and doctors. Link will follow, if available... From my point of view, the failure begins with 1), so I expect the national average fatality rate to rise from 4.6 percent as of today (04 July 2020) to just below 6 per cent in late August 2020. By that time, this suggests that a "rate of 5% or higher" in some of the states will still be below average. Turnout may be for the high end, and with 40k new cases per day on average:
4,866,000 confirmed cases
282,228 fatalities at a fatality rate of 5.8% Sounds mad, I hope they will find a way to implement 1) as fast as possible.

Currently 12 states meet the criteria and several almost meet it. Going forward as others have pointed out, new treatments and medications may give current patients a better chance. On the other hand some places may be reaching capacity soon.
Anything hire than 3%  is just a lack of testing and will be fixed

Complete re-adjustment after realizing that it will take a large number of positive cases to move the case fatality below 5%. Current average rate of positivity for each state and ideal death rate (.6%) results in 6 states still over 5% CFR. Current positivity rate and current death rate results in 8 states over 5%. Unlikely that more than 4 states will regress past 5% on CFR.

Actually 12. Main question: is that going up or down. 
Possible reason for up: 
- healtcare system overwhelmed, expected worst case: the 9 states with 4.0-4.9% will reach above 5 overall average
Possible reason for down:
- with steadily growing number of tests more non-critical cases wil be reported, expected best case:  only the 7 states with currently >6%  will stay above 5 overall average
Adjusted numbers as I just thought of fact that areas with high fatality rates may remain high if they get control of their state's epidemic and there aren't enough new cases to offset the previous.

Infection fatality rate is settling to around .6%. Effective treatments are coming online, including one that cuts fatality by a third. So the question is more whether there will be circumstances to skew the numbers. Potential scenarios: - Very high high-risk population infection rates
     - I can't think of a reasonable cause for this.
- Continued low testing among anyone other than most high risk
       - I think this is the most likely scenario where there is a high CFR, as it could be driven by a major metropolitan outbreak and a shift in testing strategy. I think still unlikely as massive testing is more plausible. Almost definitely would be isolated to a handful of states.
- Mutation increasing fatality
      Possible but extremely low probability

1.5%: 6 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1l09CRhEZw5W_yUPzabNRNWnu6VGV72mFnF3rQV6PSgE/edit?usp=sharing

IFR is approx 1%. Given advancements in treatment and intervention, CFR is unlikely to increase or remain high. By September, current case increases will be ebbing.

Currently at 12 based on chart. Numbers could go up or down based on testing (The more tests Identifying cases, the lower the rate).  As numbers skyrocket, there is more of an emphasis on testing the sick instead of the healthy.
